Tim Farron: It is time Theresa May returned to Downing Street to take charge, rather than allowing the court jester to become the crown prince.
link_name: Tim Farron: Urgent humanitarian need to protect civilians in Syria

status_message:
"I have two sons aged 14 and 12 who were both born in Barcelona, where we lived for 13 years whilst I set up and ran a destination wedding planning company. Whilst we loved the experience of living in Spain, I have always felt very British as well as European. I was worried by the politics in Catalonia where most Catalans want independence from Spain and I feared things might eventually lead to civil unrest. I wanted the boys to have an English secondary education and for us all to be around my family. I hadn't realised how much I missed my homeland but have loved everything about being back, even the weather...  until Brexit. 

I joined the Lib Dems two days after the referendum and I am now the fundraising manager for Tunbridge Wells Lib Dems. Before now I have never been politically active in my life, other than voting in general elections. I will never vote Conservative or Labour again, who in my opinion have collectively destroyed everything I love about my country. I agree wholeheartedly with the Liberal Democrats' policies and hope that the surge towards fascism will be stopped by the Lib Dem fightback. My country and children's' futures depend on it in my heartfelt opinion."

Clare Bishop, 44, mother of two
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I was brought up very much as a liberal (with a small L) scientist, taught to form my own opinions and question the status quo. I've voted Lib Dem pretty much all my life. Initially this was to do with occupying the middle ground, but time spent living and working in Germany has made me sensitive to the problems faced by immigrants and understand that all people everywhere should have the same rights. As a scientist I make decisions based on rational reasoning and evidence rather than emotions. That doesn't mean that I don't get emotional though – Brexit makes me very sad and angry!"

Carol Stanier, 40, Freelance Science Editor, Royston, North Herts.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"On 24 June 2016 everything changed. I have two little girls, and was suddenly terrified for the world, the country, even the town I was raising them in. We live on the outskirts of Barnsley, one of the most pro-leave areas of the UK. It suddenly felt like it was no longer enough to sit in my kitchen and complain to my husband about politics. I felt powerless and frustrated and with an overwhelming need to DO something. So I joined the Lib Dems. I've already had the opportunity to work with some incredible campaigners. It's been pretty amazing. And I think the best is yet to come."

Hannah Kitching, 37, full time mum, Penistone, South Yorks.
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I was born in 1945 whilst the war was still on. I am the son of a refugee and a migrant worker. My father escaped from France and flew with the Free French till just after D Day when he didn't return. My mother came from the Irish Republic to work as a nurse - in those days refugees and immigrants were welcome and needed. 

Why do I support the Lib Dems? I believe in social justice, equality, and since the 60s I have always supported the Liberals when I began to realise what the world was about.  In those days we thought it could only improve, and a lot has, but with the far right putsch since 27% of the population voted for Brexit and May and her clique taking us down a long dark tunnel it is time to stand up and be counted and to try and minimise the damage. You look at the improvements and protections since we joined the EU; if these are rolled back I fear for my children's and grandchildren's future and the future of our country. So let the fight back start."

Damien Dill, 71, retired finance manager and living in Hereford
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
Ming Campbell: There are about 3 million people living in the United Kingdom who are EU nationals but not from the United Kingdom. Some of them are mothers and fathers of British citizens because their children are born in Britain. They are husbands and wives of British citizens.

Support our Right To Stay campaign to fight for EU citizens right to live in the UK as well as UK citizens rights to live in the EU.

status_message:
"I became a Lib Dem after being a Labour member, councillor and mayor of Lowestoft. I am passionate about fairness and internationalism, I am socially liberal and care about recognising that individuals need unique opportunities. I also feel there is a covenant between state and society which provides safety and wellbeing in return for being productive within our society.

To deliver these things I believe in fiscal responsibility and that money raised from people and organisations in tax should be treated with the greatest care and with as little waste as possible. I didn't leave Labour, I came home to the Lib Dems, the only party who marry all of my political beliefs."

Tod Sullivan, 39, Mental Health Service Manager, Lowestoft, Suffolk

status_message: Theresa May's arrogance is breathtaking

"I was a Labour member, and was one of the people cheering (initially) when Jeremy Corbyn became leader of the Labour party, perhaps this was a chance for fairer treatment of UK residents including immigrants, more house building, a focus on keeping the NHS as it is etc.

I was pleased to find out that Labour was supporting the remain campaign in the EU referendum and was myself involved in the campaign, but the way it has been dealt with since the loss has been a joke, and it became clear to me that I was not being listened to. The Liberal Democrats seem to be the only people listening to me and others like me, so here I am."

Luke Carter, 35, programmer, Horsham

status_message:
"Brexit has changed me from being a sleeping Lib Dem into a door-knocking activist! I was devastated by the vote to leave the EU and wanted to do something positive – something more than just tweeting furiously and ranting with friends. Joining the Liberal Democrats was the obvious step to take.

To me, being a Lib Dem is about being European as well as British, and about fighting for the future of liberal values against the rise of nationalism and populism. Being part of the Lib Dems gives me hope that we can succeed, and I am proud to be here."

Naomi McCarthy, 45, editor/web manager in the arts, London

status_message:
"I joined the party in 2015, following the General Election, as I felt liberalism (and, within 18 months centrism and moderate politics) were under threat. The more involved with the party I got, the more I found Lib Dems welcoming, encouraging and open and it ignited my passion to help more and contribute more.

I've found a passion for knocking on doors, taking to people and improving my local area - nearly two years to the day after I decided to join the Lib Dems, now I am the party's candidate for Chapel & Hope Valley in 2017's Derbyshire County Council elections."

- Charles Lawley, 28, press officer for a humanitarian aid charity, from Chapel-en-le-Frith, High Peak, Derbyshire

You too can join the Liberal Democrats > www.libdems.org.uk/join

status_message:
"I have always voted Liberal Democrat, but only felt the need to join the party after the EU referendum. Like many others, I have become steadily more appalled by the undemocratic actions of the current government over the past months.

Since joining the Liberal Democrats, I have become actively involved with my local group and been elected as the first Liberal Democrat councillor in my village. I joined to help make a difference and not stand idly by as this government attempts to drag us wholesale out of the EU without a thought to the consequences."

- Rachel McGann, 43, primary school teacher, Bedfordshire

You too can join the Liberal Democrats: www.libdems.org.uk/join
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I had a varied professional life. For the last 20 years I was a social worker in mental health, young offenders and management posts. 
My first job was on the fairground of the Grand Pier when I was 14 years. When the pier closed for the winter I was 15 years and unemployed. Unemployment did not suit me and I wanted adventure so I joined the British Army as an apprentice. My time at the Royal Army Medical Corps Apprentice College continued until the age of 33. I said farewell to the Army and became a student at Lancaster University where I spent five fun filled years, completing a post-grad social work course and taking a job as a youth worker.

My life experience led me to the Labour Party - and it also led me to leave it. I have spent many years in Europe and as I looked at the threadbare political landscape in my beloved England, my decision was to join the Liberal Democrats. I was quickly followed by my beloved wife Diana."

- Roland C Powell, 66, retired, from Higham, Barnsley

You too can join the Liberal Democrats: www.libdems.org.uk/join
link_name: Timeline Photos

status_message:
"I had never been a member of a political party up until 27th June 2016. I had no interest in politics – I left it to others, unshakably confident that they would do the right thing. The 23rd June happened and they didn't do the right thing. Worse still there was a sharp rise in hate crimes and racism. I was devastated.

I raged at the world in general then someone shared a quote "all it takes for evil to prevail is for good men to do nothing". That was it - I realised that I had to properly get involved and make my voice heard. I want to live in a sustainable, open and compassionate country. So I joined the Liberal Democrats – and here I am, County Council Candidate for Diss & Roydon making my voice heard!"

- Tracy Scoggins, 51, Diss, Norfolk

You too can join the Liberal Democrats: www.libdems.org.uk/join
link_name: Timeline Photos

I joined the Liberal Democrats in July, disappointed with the referendum result and worried that the direction of the Conservative government was becoming insular and no longer positive, outward thinking and globalised. 

Since joining I have become active with the health and care association and support their communications across social media at a time when the crisis in health and care needs addressing head on. With family members that work on the front line of these essential services, the strain currently upon them is something I feel passionately about and want to support the party with."

status_message:
"I've always voted Lib Dem, but being a LibDem has become increasingly important to me over the last 10 years. I see us as the only party that consistently stands for the values I want my children to cherish. Values like treating everyone with respect, regardless of who they are, what they look like or what language they speak. It's also the only party that strikes the right balance between what we do nationally and how we position ourselves internationally - we are all on this planet together. That's why after the referendum, I decided that I had to do more. I'm now the Prospective Parliamentary Candidate for my London constituency, Dulwich and West Norwood."

Gail Kent, 41, from London

status_message:
"I am a Lib Dem because I have always felt strongly that centre-ground, coalition governance is the most effective way to govern a modern liberal democracy. Aside from that, the Lib Dems best represent my views on a number of issues, like mental health, climate change, EU membership and the economy, so they're a natural choice for me.

Since the vote to leave the EU, with the Lib Dems leading the charge against hard Brexit, it feels as though people are coming around to the idea that the Lib Dems may not be the 'half-in, half-out' party they once thought it was - we're standing vocally in opposition to the government on EU membership, climate, the economy, and asking the tough questions. Labour doesn't seem interested in acting for the 48% who voted remain. I hope people realise that."

Ailbhe Rees, salesperson, from London

status_message:
On 6 August 1885, late at night in the Commons an amendment criminalised homosexual acts. The only discussion was over the penalty to be imposed. The whole debate had four speakers and it lasted four minutes, but it led to 75,000 men being convicted. Alan Turing was one of those.

http://www.pinknews.co.uk/2017/02/03/lord-sharkey-why-i-fought-to-get-a-pardon-for-convicted-gay-and-bi-men/
